metadata.case_name: Employees of Model Mills, Nagpur v. Model Mills, Nagpur & Ors.

facts.text: Model Mills, Nagpur is a public limited company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act.
On July 18, 1959, Central Government took over management of the Mills under s. 18-A of Industries Development and Regulation Act, 1951, and appointed 3rd respondent as authorised Controller.

On March 25, 1960, State of Bombay (now Maharashtra) declared Mills a relief undertaking under ss. 3 and 4 of Bombay Relief Undertakings Special Provisions Act, 1958, for one year from March 26, 1960 to March 25, 1961, exempting it from s. 16 of State Act and Chapter V-A of Industrial Disputes Act.
Appellants (eight permanent employees) abstained from work on December 15, 1960, during the notification period.
1st respondent (Factory Manager) issued notices to show cause why employees should not be dismissed for joining illegal strike.
Factory Manager dismissed employees on January 6, 1961.
Employees filed writ petition for mandamus for reinstatement on January 12, 1961, in Bombay High Court; dismissed with liberty to file fresh petition.
State Government exempted Mills from s. 16 of Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 (State Act).
Employees filed applications before Assistant Commissioner of Labour for reinstatement with back wages on April 25, 1961.
Assistant Commissioner allowed applications on September 29, 1961, holding no illegal strike, dismissal unsustainable, directed reinstatement with back wages.
Mills filed revision to State Industrial Court; allowed on February 16, 1962, holding applications not maintainable, but agreed no illegal strike on merits.
Employees filed Special Civil Application No. 315 of 1962 under Arts. 226 and 227 for certiorari to quash dismissal orders and direct reinstatement.
Bombay High Court (Nagpur Bench) dismissed writ on August 12, 1963, holding no right to reinstatement under common law, s.16 not applicable due to exemption at dismissal time.
Exemption extended on March 8, 1961 for further one year, but s.16 exemption withdrawn on April 4, 1961.
s.16 of State Act made applicable to textile industry including Mills from March 1, 1951, till exemption.

legal_issues.text: Whether the right of a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement, in appropriate cases, exists de hors s. 16 of the State Act?

Whether by reason of the State Government's exemption of the industry from the operation of s. 16 on the date when the employees were dismissed from service, their right to apply for reinstatement ceased to exist?

petitioner_arguments.text: Though industry exempt from s.16 at dismissal, there was existing industrial dispute on April 4, 1961 when exemption withdrawn; applications filed within six months, so could invoke s.16.

respondent_arguments.text: Right to reinstatement granted only by s.16; exempt at dismissal, so no right; exemption gives immunity, not mere suspension.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.16 State Act; Bombay Act ss.3,4

respondent_arguments.text: Withdrawal of exemption prospective only, no retrospective effect.
Validity of dismissal not determined by High Court, remit for consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Right to claim reinstatement exists de hors s.16, which only provides procedure/forum; recognised post Industrial Disputes Act 1947 and Federal Court precedent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.16 recognises but does not confer the right.

court_reasoning.text: Exemption under Bombay Act suspends remedy under s.16, not the right itself; status quo ante restored on withdrawal, application within 6 months valid.
Dismissal held wrongful by Asst Commissioner and Industrial Court (on merits); no need to remit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validity already concluded in employees' favour.

court_reasoning.text: No retrospective operation issue; dispute existing when s.16 applicable post-withdrawal, per Birla Brothers precedent.

holdings.text: Right of employee to claim reinstatement on wrongful dismissal exists independently of s.16 State Act.
Exemption under Bombay Act suspends remedy under s.16 but not the right; enforceable post-withdrawal if within time limit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Recognised jurisdiction of industrial tribunals to order reinstatement as industrial dispute; right exists post-1947 Act.
Act applies to existing/continuing disputes without retrospective effect issue.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 (State Act XXIII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides forum for reinstatement claims; applicable to textile industry from 1951; exemption suspended remedy not right.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Relief Undertakings (Special Provisions) Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification declared Mills relief undertaking, exempting from s.16 State Act; withdrawal restores status quo.

statutes_cited.name: Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Central Govt took over Mills management.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for High Court writ petition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Bombay High Court and order of State Industrial Court set aside; award of Assistant Commissioner of Labour restored directing reinstatement with back wages.
outcome.relief_granted: Reinstatement with back wages to appellants.
outcome.costs: Appellants entitled to costs in Supreme Court paid by respondent No. 1.

key_quotes.text: The right of a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement, in appropriate cases, exists de hors s. 16 of the State Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on independent existence of right.

key_quotes.text: Section 16 provides a forum for a dismissed employee to claim reinstatement but does not create a right.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The effect of an exemption granted by the notification issued under the Bombay Act is not to destroy the right but to suspend the remedy prescribed by s. 16.
key_quotes.speaker: court
